question.title: Effective way to transform a few nodes contents of feeds

node.contents:
• I need to "proxy" a feed
  • and leave most of the nodes unspoiled
  • and transform the content of a few known nodes by calling some java methods
  • and return the transformed feed

astNode.text:
• I need to "proxy" a feed
  • and leave most of the nodes unspoiled
  • and transform the content of a few known nodes by calling some java methods
  • and return the transformed feed

node.contents: Of course I prefer to avoid - loading in memory the whole feed - transform other nodes - bad performance

astNode.text: Of course I prefer to avoid - loading in memory the whole feed - transform other nodes - bad performance

node.contents: The transformContent is of course a static method of MyClass

astNode.text: The transformContent is of course a static method of MyClass

node.contents: Thanks all for your answers : Here is the final result

astNode.text: Thanks all for your answers : Here is the final result

node.contents: And the XSLT which call the java method for a kind of node and leave the others untouched

astNode.text: And the XSLT which call the java method for a kind of node and leave the others untouched

units.rawText:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="ISO-8859-1"?>
<xsl:stylesheet version="1.0" xmlns:xsl="http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform" xmlns:java="http://xml.apache.org/xslt/java">


<xsl:output method="xml" encoding="UTF-8" indent="yes" omit-xml-declaration="no" />


<xsl:template match="CHANGED_NODE">
    <xsl:element name="CHANGED_NODE">
        <xsl:value-of select="java:com.mypackage.MyClass.tranformContent(.)"/>
   </xsl:element>
</xsl:template>

<xsl:template match="node()|@*">
<xsl:copy><xsl:apply-templates select="node()|@*"/></xsl:copy>
</xsl:template>

</xsl:stylesheet>

node.contents: Well I don't know about the "not loading into memory" but if you want to transform xml you should consider xslt and xpath.

astNode.text: Well I don't know about the "not loading into memory" but if you want to transform xml you should consider xslt and xpath.

node.contents: Since you want to avoid memory overhead you should replace the DOMSource and DOMResult usage with SAX equivalents. The String and XML util class usage should be obvious from context.

astNode.text: Since you want to avoid memory overhead you should replace the DOMSource and DOMResult usage with SAX equivalents. The String and XML util class usage should be obvious from context.
